published_attributes.title: Introduction
published_attributes.serialized_body:
In this course I would like to briefly introduce to you the FastApi framework, which is getting more and more popular nowadays and surely is worth to learn!

Scope:

  • Framework characteristics
  • Installation
  • Hello World app
  • Handling requests
  • Asynchronous routines
  • Deploying

At the end of the course you will find a quick quiz. I wish you effective learning and good luck! :)

blocks.text: In this course I would like to briefly introduce to you the FastApi framework, which is getting more and more popular nowadays and surely is worth to learn!

published_attributes.title: Framework characteristics
published_attributes.serialized_body:
• Easy to learn
  • High performance - comparable to NodeJS and Go
  • According to TechEmpower benchmarks one of the fastest Python Web frameworks
  • SqlAlchemy based database connection
  • Provides interactive documentation - set up by default
  • Data validation and serialization with Pydantic and standard Python typings
  • Enables asynchronizing the code easily

blocks.text: High performance - comparable to NodeJS and Go
According to TechEmpower benchmarks one of the fastest Python Web frameworks
Provides interactive documentation - set up by default
Data validation and serialization with Pydantic and standard Python typings

published_attributes.title: Starlette
published_attributes.serialized_body:
FastAPI is a framework built on top of Starlette, so it provides its features like:

  • WebSocket support
  • GraphQL support
  • In process background tasks
  • Session and cookie support
  • Startup and shutdown events

published_attributes.title: Installation
published_attributes.serialized_body:
All you need to start your first FastAPI app can be installed via pip:

pip install fastapi
pip install uvicorn

Alternatively you can use hypercorn instead of uvicorn.

blocks.text: All you need to start your first FastAPI app can be installed via pip:
Alternatively you can use hypercorn instead of uvicorn.

published_attributes.title: Hello World app
published_attributes.serialized_body:
• Only 1 file, 5 lines of code!
  • Run locally with:uvicorn SCRIPT_NAME:app --reload
  • By default it runs on port 8000, try: localhost:8000/
localhost:8000/docs for Swagger
localhost:8000/redoc for Redoc

blocks.text: By default it runs on port 8000, try: localhost:8000/

draft_attributes.title: Hello World app
draft_attributes.serialized_body:
• Only 1 file, 5 lines of code!
  • Run locally with:uvicorn SCRIPT_NAME:app --reload
  • By default it runs on port 8000, try: localhost:8000/
localhost:8000/docs for Swagger
localhost:8000/redoc for Redoc

blocks.text: By default it runs on port 8000, try: localhost:8000/

published_attributes.title: Passing parameters
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Path parameters: 

@app.get("/some_path/{some_parameter}")                def some_handler(some_parameter: str): …

Query parameters - just add them to your handler function, you can set them also as optionals:

@app.get("/some_path)
def some_handler(some_parameter: Optional[str] = None)

Remember that FastAPI automatically handles missing or redundant ending backslash!

blocks.text: Query parameters - just add them to your handler function, you can set them also as optionals:
Remember that FastAPI automatically handles missing or redundant ending backslash!

published_attributes.title: Retrieving request body
published_attributes.serialized_body:
• Effortless with usage of Pydantic
  • Create a class deriving from pydantic.BaseModel and define expected data structure
  • Provide typings and mark optional attributes
  • Use pydantic.Field() to define attributes limits
  • Pydantic automatically generates response error message when request body is not valid
  • Remember if you want to validate email strings, you need to install email-validator via PIP
  • Please try out this code and test it with few POST requests

blocks.text: Create a class deriving from pydantic.BaseModel and define expected data structure
Provide typings and mark optional attributes
Use pydantic.Field() to define attributes limits
Pydantic automatically generates response error message when request body is not valid
Remember if you want to validate email strings, you need to install email-validator via PIP
Please try out this code and test it with few POST requests

published_attributes.title: Returning an object
published_attributes.serialized_body: With usage of model classes it is very easy to return data. You don’t have to handle model class object serialization.  Please check up this code example.

published_attributes.title: Use async/await statements
published_attributes.serialized_body:
• In a simple way you can define asynchronous coroutines
  • You don’t need any middleware or configuration
  • Prescribe the code and try and send concurrent requests to /async and /sync in this order

blocks.text: In a simple way you can define asynchronous coroutines
You don’t need any middleware or configuration
Prescribe the code and try and send concurrent requests to /async and /sync in this order
